member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.CounterCreationData

member.summary: Raw value of the counter.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.CounterSample.BaseValue
member.summary: Optional base raw value for the counter (only used if multiple counter based).

member.summary: Raw system frequency

member.summary: Raw counter frequency

member.summary: Raw counter frequency

member.summary: Raw timestamp

member.summary: Raw high fidelity timestamp

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.CounterSample.CounterType
member.summary: Counter type

member.summary: Static functions to calculate the performance value off the sample

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.CounterSample.Calculate(System.Diagnostics.CounterSample,System.Diagnostics.CounterSample)
member.summary: Static functions to calculate the performance value off the samples

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.CounterSampleCalculator
member.summary: Set of utility functions for interpreting the counter data

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.CounterSampleCalculator.GetElapsedTime(System.Diagnostics.CounterSample,System.Diagnostics.CounterSample)
member.summary: Converts 100NS elapsed time to fractional seconds

member.summary: Computes the calculated value given a raw counter sample.

member.summary: Computes the calculated value given a raw counter sample.

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.InstanceData
member.summary: A holder of instance data.

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.InstanceDataCollection
member.summary: A collection containing all the instance data for a counter. This collection is contained in the when using the method.

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.InstanceDataCollectionCollection
member.summary: The collection returned from the method. that contains all the counter and instance data. The collection contains an InstanceDataCollection object for each counter. Each InstanceDataCollection object contains the performance data for all counters for that instance. In other words the data is indexed by counter name and then by instance name.

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceCounter
member.summary: Performance Counter component. This class provides support for NT Performance counters. It handles both the existing counters (accessible by Perf Registry Interface) and user defined (extensible) counters. This class is a part of a larger framework, that includes the perf dll object and perf service.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceCounter.#ctor
member.summary: The defaut constructor. Creates the perf counter object

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceCounter.#ctor(System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Creates the Performance Counter Object

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceCounter.#ctor(System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Creates the Performance Counter Object on local machine.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceCounter.#ctor(System.String,System.String,System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Creates the Performance Counter Object on local machine.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceCounter.#ctor(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Creates the Performance Counter Object, assumes that it's a single instance

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceCounter.#ctor(System.String,System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Creates the Performance Counter Object, assumes that it's a single instance

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceCounter.CategoryName
member.summary: Returns the performance category name for this performance counter

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceCounter.CounterHelp
member.summary: Returns the description message for this performance counter

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceCounter.CounterName
member.summary: Sets/returns the performance counter name for this performance counter

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceCounter.CounterType
member.summary: Sets/Returns the counter type for this performance counter

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceCounter.InstanceName
member.summary: Sets/returns an instance name for this performance counter

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceCounter.ReadOnly
member.summary: Returns true if counter is read only (system counter, foreign extensible counter or remote counter)

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceCounter.MachineName
member.summary: Set/returns the machine name for this performance counter

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceCounter.RawValue
member.summary: Directly accesses the raw value of this counter. If counter type is of a 32-bit size, it will truncate the value given to 32 bits. This can be significantly more performant for scenarios where the raw value is sufficient. Note that this only works for custom counters created using this component, non-custom counters will throw an exception if this property is accessed.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceCounter.Close
member.summary: Frees all the resources allocated by this counter

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceCounter.CloseSharedResources
member.summary: Frees all the resources allocated for all performance counters, frees File Mapping used by extensible counters, unloads dll's used to read counters.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceCounter.Decrement
member.summary: Decrements counter by one using an efficient atomic operation.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceCounter.IncrementBy(System.Int64)
member.summary: Increments the value of this counter. If counter type is of a 32-bit size, it'll truncate the value given to 32 bits. This method uses a mutex to guarantee correctness of the operation in case of multiple writers. This method should be used with caution because of the negative impact on performance due to creation of the mutex.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceCounter.Increment
member.summary: Increments counter by one using an efficient atomic operation.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceCounter.InitializeImpl
member.summary: Intializes required resources

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceCounter.NextSample
member.summary: Obtains a counter sample and returns the raw value for it.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceCounter.NextValue
member.summary: Obtains a counter sample and returns the calculated value for it. NOTE: For counters whose calculated value depend upon 2 counter reads, the very first read will return 0.0.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceCounter.RemoveInstance
member.summary: Removes this counter instance from the shared memory

member.summary: Gets/sets the Machine name

member.summary: Returns true if the counter is registered for this category

member.summary: Returns true if the counter is registered for this category on a particular machine.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceCounterCategory.Exists(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Returns true if the category is registered in the machine.

member.summary: Returns the instance names for a given category

member.summary: Returns an array of counters in this category for the given instance.

member.summary: Returns true if the instance already exists for the category specified.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceCounterCategory.InstanceExists(System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Returns true if the instance already exists for this category and machine specified.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceCounterCategory.ReadCategory
member.summary: Reads all the counter and instance data of this performance category. Note that reading the entire category at once can be as efficient as reading a single counter because of the way the system provides the data.

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceCounterType
member.summary: Enum of friendly names to counter types (maps directory to the native types)

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceData.CounterSet
member.summary: CounterSet is equivalent to "Counter Object" in native performance counter terminology, or "Counter Category" in previous framework releases. It defines a abstract grouping of counters, where each counter defines measurable matrix. In the new performance counter infrastructure, CounterSet is defined by GUID called CounterSetGuid, and is hosted inside provider application, which is also defined by another GUID called ProviderGuid.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceData.CounterSet.#ctor(System.Guid,System.Guid,System.Diagnostics.PerformanceData.CounterSetInstanceType)
member.summary: CounterSet constructor.
member.param: ProviderGuid identifies the provider application. A provider identified by ProviderGuid could publish several CounterSets defined by different CounterSetGuids
CounterSetGuid identifies the specific CounterSet. CounterSetGuid should be unique.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceData.CounterSet.AddCounter(System.Int32,System.Diagnostics.PerformanceData.CounterType)
member.summary: Add non-displayable new counter to CounterSet; that is, perfmon would not display the counter.
member.param: CounterId uniquely identifies the counter within CounterSet

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceData.CounterSet.AddCounter(System.Int32,System.Diagnostics.PerformanceData.CounterType,System.String)
member.summary: Add named new counter to CounterSet.
member.param: CounterId uniquely identifies the counter within CounterSet
This is friendly name to help provider developers as indexer. and it might not match what is displayed in counter consumption applications lie perfmon.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceData.CounterSet.CreateCounterSetInstance(System.String)
member.summary: Create instances of the CounterSet. Created CounterSetInstance identifies active identity and tracks raw counter data for that identity.
member.param: Friendly name identifies the instance. InstanceName would be shown in counter consumption applications like perfmon.

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceData.CounterSetInstance
member.summary: CounterSetInstance class maps to "Instance" in native performance counter implementation.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceData.CounterSetInstance.Counters
member.summary: Access CounterSetInstanceCounterDataSet property. Developers can then use defined indexer to access specific CounterData object to query/update raw counter data.

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceData.CounterData
member.summary: CounterData class is used to store actual raw counter data. It is the value element within CounterSetInstanceCounterDataSet, which is part of CounterSetInstance.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceData.CounterData.#ctor(System.Int64*)
member.summary: CounterData constructor
member.param: The memory location to store raw counter data

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceData.CounterData.Value
member.summary: Value property it used to query/update actual raw counter data.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceData.CounterData.RawValue
member.summary: RawValue property it used to query/update actual raw counter data. This property is not thread-safe and should only be used for performance-critical single-threaded access.

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceData.CounterSetInstanceCounterDataSet
member.summary: CounterSetInstanceCounterDataSet is part of CounterSetInstance class, and is used to store raw counter data for all counters added in CounterSet.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceData.CounterSetInstanceCounterDataSet.Item(System.Int32)
member.summary: CounterId indexer to access specific CounterData object.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceData.CounterSetInstanceCounterDataSet.Item(System.String)
member.summary: CounterName indexer to access specific CounterData object.
member.param: CounterName that matches one CounterSet::AddCounter() call

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceData.CounterSetInstanceType
member.summary: Enum of friendly names to CounterSet instance type (maps directory to the native types defined in perflib.h)

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceData.CounterSetInstanceType.Single
member.summary: Single means that at any time CounterSet should only have at most 1 active instance.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceData.CounterSetInstanceType.Multiple
member.summary: Multiple means that CounterSet could have multiple active instances.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceData.CounterSetInstanceType.GlobalAggregate
member.summary: GlobalAggregate means that CounterSet could have multiple active instances, but counter consumption applications (for example, perfmon) would aggregate raw counter data from different instances.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceData.CounterSetInstanceType.GlobalAggregateWithHistory
member.summary: GlobalAggregateWithHistory is similar to GlobalAggregate, but counter consumption applications (for example, permfon) would aggregate raw counter data not only from active instances, but also from instances since consumption applications start.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceData.CounterSetInstanceType.MultipleAggregate
member.summary: MultipleInstancesWithAggregate acts similar to Multiple, but it also generate aggregated instace "_Total" that hosts aggregated raw counter data from all other instances.

member.name: F:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceData.CounterSetInstanceType.InstanceAggregate
member.summary: InstanceAggregate only exists in Longhonr Server. Counter consumption applications aggregate raw counter data for active instances with the same instance name.

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.PerformanceData.CounterType
member.summary: Enum of friendly names to counter types (maps directory to the native types defined in winperf.h).

member.name: P:System.SR.InvalidParameter
member.summary: Invalid value '{1}' for parameter '{0}'.

member.name: P:System.SR.CategoryHelpCorrupt
member.summary: Cannot load Category Help data because an invalid index '{0}' was read from the registry. Performance counters on the machine may need to be repaired.

member.name: P:System.SR.CounterNameCorrupt
member.summary: Cannot load Counter Name data because an invalid index '{0}' was read from the registry. Performance counters on the machine may need to be repaired.

member.name: P:System.SR.CounterDataCorrupt
member.summary: Cannot load Performance Counter data because an unexpected registry key value type was read from '{0}'. Performance counters on the machine may need to be repaired.

member.name: P:System.SR.InstanceNameTooLong
member.summary: Instance names used for writing to custom counters must be 127 characters or less.

member.name: P:System.SR.ProcessLifetimeNotValidInGlobal
member.summary: PerformanceCounterInstanceLifetime.Process is not valid in the global shared memory. If your performance counter category was created with an older version of the Framework, it uses the global shared memory. Either use PerformanceCounterInstanceLifetime. ...

member.name: P:System.SR.CountersOOM
member.summary: Custom counters file view is out of memory.

member.name: P:System.SR.MappingCorrupted
member.summary: Cannot continue the current operation, the performance counters memory mapping has been corrupted.

member.name: P:System.SR.SingleInstanceOnly
member.summary: Category '{0}' is marked as single-instance. Performance counters in this category can only be created without instance names.

member.name: P:System.SR.MultiInstanceOnly
member.summary: Category '{0}' is marked as multi-instance. Performance counters in this category can only be created with instance names.

member.name: P:System.SR.CantConvertProcessToGlobal
member.summary: An instance with a lifetime of Process can only be accessed from a PerformanceCounter with the InstanceLifetime set to PerformanceCounterInstanceLifetime.Process.

member.name: P:System.SR.CantConvertGlobalToProcess
member.summary: An instance with a lifetime of Global can only be accessed from a PerformanceCounter with the InstanceLifetime set to PerformanceCounterInstanceLifetime.Global.

member.name: P:System.SR.InstanceAlreadyExists
member.summary: Instance '{0}' already exists with a lifetime of Process. It cannot be recreated or reused until it has been removed or until the process using it has exited.

member.name: P:System.SR.SharedMemoryGhosted
member.summary: Cannot access shared memory, AppDomain has been unloaded.

member.name: T:Interop.BOOL
member.summary: Blittable version of Windows BOOL type. It is convenient in situations where manual marshalling is required, or to avoid overhead of regular bool marshalling.
member.remarks: Some Windows APIs return arbitrary integer values although the return type is defined as BOOL. It is best to never compare BOOL to TRUE. Always use bResult != BOOL.FALSE or bResult == BOOL.FALSE .
